item.title: Professional highlights
item.description:
• Feb 2022: Scheduled to present Does Gender Gap in Test Score Exist? Evidence from Administrative Data from Afghanistan paper at Dickinson College, Carlisle, PA.

  • Jan 2022: I will be presenting in The Effect of Regulating Healthcare Workers on Patients and Practitioners symposium organized by the Institute for Humane Studies and co-hosted by Arkansas Center for Research in Economics on January 28th, 2022 at 3:00 – 6:00 PM ET. Registration is free and available here.

  • Jan 2022: Paper with Juan Tomas Sayago and Alicia Plemmons titled Spatial Spillovers, and the Productivity Compensation Gap in the United States is forthcoming in The Annals of Regional Science.

  • Jan 2022: I presented the paper titled Grading Policy, Email Nudges, and Grade Outcomes presented at PASSHE Virtual Conference On Teaching And Learning.

  • Nov 2021: Paper with Jayash Paudel and Subuna Basnet titled Natural Disasters and International Labor Migration: Empirical Evidence from Nepal’s Earthquake published in World Development.

  • Nov 2021: Paper with Alicia Plemmons titled Productivity Spillovers and the Productivity-Compensation Gap is published in Spatial Economic Analysis.

  • Nov 2021: Invited talk at Gulati Institute of Finance and Taxation– An autonomous research institute under the State Government of Kerala, India to speak on Healthcare Occupational Regulation and Healthcare Professional’s Mobility.

  • Nov 2021: Invited talk at Ural Federal University, Russia where I presented The Dark Side of the ShaleBoom: County-Level Analysis paper, joint research with Luyi Han.

  • Sep 2021: Invited talk at National Council of State Boards of Nursing (NCSBN) on Impact of Nurse Licensure Compact, which is joint research with Sriparna Ghosh and Conor Norris.

  • Jun 2021: Paper with Kazi Sohag titled “The Fracking Boom and Crime Rates in the Rural American States: Some Critical Insights” is published in The Extractive Industries and Society.

  • Mar 2012: David Mitchell director for Arkansas Center for Research in Economics cites my work Scope of practice laws and the mobility of nurse practitioners in an article and in testimony for Arkansas State Legislature for bill number HB1254 - To Authorize the Arkansas Medicaid Program to Recognize an Advanced Practice Registered Nurse as a Primary Care Provider which passed into law on May 2021.

  • Feb 2021: Scott Cunningham author of the book Causal Inference: The Mixtape asked what my thoughts were on various online casual inference courses on the different platforms (for free) that I took. I made a Twitter thread; see here. Many researchers, students, and causal inference enthusiasts loved it.

  • Jan 2021: Paper with Alicia Plemmons titled The Impact of Economic Freedom on Startups is published in the Journal of Regional Analysis & Policy. Bridwell Institute for Economic Freedom shared our paper on their Twitter @SMUCoxBridwell.

  • 2020: Prescription Drug Abuse Policy System- PDAPS.org put my working paper County-Level Assessment of Prescription Drug Monitoring Program and Opioid Prescription Rate in their resources. http://pdaps.org/resources.

  • 2020: Gov. Whitmer repeals rule, she says it helped Michigan fight Coronavirus @MackinacCenter. The article cites my work Scope of practice laws and the mobility of nurse practitioners.

  • 2020: Scope of practice laws and the mobility of nurse practitioners is published in the Journal of Labor Research. Highlights are on Twitter. CSOR St. Francis University, The Knee Center for the Study of Occupational Regulation at Saint Francis mentions this paper on LinkedIn.

  • 2020: Paper with Elham Erfanian and Alexandre Scarcioffolo titled The political economy of Vermont’s abortion bill is published in Applied Economics Letters.

item.title: Teachings
item.description:
Assistant Professor, Shippensburg University of Pennsylvania

  • ECO 393: Regional Economics Spring 2022
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Spring 2022
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Fall 2021
  • ECO 113: Principles of Economics Fall 2021
  • ECO 280: Managerial Economics Summer B 2021
  • ECO 393: Economic Analysis of Big Data Spring 2021
  • ECO 101: Principles of Macroeconomics Spring 2021
  • ECO 113: Principles of Economics Fall 2020

Selected Student Comments Shippensburg University Fall 2021

“The energy that Shishir had while teaching helped to keep his class engaged, and his humor helped to lighten the mood for an otherwise stressful subject.”

“How upfront and set the schedule was, so I always knew what was due and when.”

“Consistency in material each week and the willingness to work with students. Very modern class.”

“He greatly appreciates student feedback and wants everyone to succeed. You know what to expect each week as far as assignments and quizzes, that helps me to do well because I can effectively plan my week.”

“Managerial Economics is already a difficult course, however, Professor Shakya gave us the tools to make it easier for us to understand it.”

“Shishir teaches this course in a way that makes the material easier to understand, he uses many examples and relates the material to the real world.”

“Professor Shakya is truly dedicated to the success of all of his students. He developed a unique weekly grading system in which you could see your course grade as the weeks continue to go. On top of that, he also does not want to see any of his students fail, so he has methods he uses to try to motivate his students to bring up their grade. He is very knowledgeable within his field, which really helps as he can find things that can help us understand a particular concept better. Finally, he always makes sure that if the lecture’s content is heavy that he will give us a five minute break to break up the amount of things he is teaching at once”

“He is by far my favorite teacher here ever. I really liked what I was learning and how he taught me. He has to be the most dedicated techer I have met here and I am completely grateful.”

“Although I don’t have much interest in economics in general, this class managed to hold my attention. The professor did an excellent job this semester.”

“The professor was very flexible in teaching his class. Not only did that flexibility help in his class, it also helped for outside courses too. Teaching in this manner helped me achieve the highest grade possible.”

“I really enjoyed Shishir’s class. He did a great job at wanting you to succeed and teaching the class a tough subject.”

“He is very knowledgeable about the course matter and is willing to help anyone struggling inside or outside of class.”

“The most positive aspect of this course would be that Professor Shakya was willing to listen to his students and use the feedback that he received to better the course and our overall experience.”

“The professor was very passionate about what he was teaching, and personable with the students. It made coming to class more enjoyable. The prof also gave students the opportunity to earn many points, which not a lot of professors do.”

“The most positive aspect of this course was that Professor Shishir was very personable and brought energy to the classroom.”

“Mr. Shishir took time to go over everything we were struggling on and he understands when we are all worn out and need a break”

“I like the overall setup of the course. It was straightforward and was organized well. There were no surprise grades and it was all pretty fair. As a student you knew what was expected and that is something I enjoy. [Other] professors can be negligent on notifying about random assignment but since this was the same structure every week, it was easy to prepare for and manage the time to work on the class.”

“I really enjoyed Professor Shakya and think is class will really aid me in the future. I especially enjoyed his investment unit at the end of the class; I feel as if I can really implement it in the future.”

“Shishir made a very scary course tolerable and allowed me, who is terrible at math, to understand complex math”

“Overall, Shakya, or Shishir as he wants us to refer to him as, is a very caring and smart professor. He’s young, which helps him relate to his students more, and willing to receive feedback, given that he usually asks us for it all of the time. He understands that ECO 280 is a pretty heavy course for those not majoring in economics, so he makes sure to give his student’s enough resources to get through it.”

“I only agree that the subject of the course interests me because of this professor. I had no interest or even a like of economics before taking this class, and Professor Shakya changed that. I never really understood economics and so it frustrated me more than anything else. But after this course I understand economics and have an interest in it. Still no love for the subject, but now a healthy interest.”

“He did a very good job teaching us the subjects that were brought up on the syllabus. My favorite part of the class was at the end when he talked about investing and the stock market.”

“Best Prof I have had since my 2 years I’ve been going to ship, cares about his students and wants them to do well in his class. Very good at teaching and loved getting to know him.”

“He is very laid back and gave us breaks when we seemed to get overwhelmed with other school work. I appreciated that so much. He was very nice as you advanced through the class.”

“He made sure to stop and make sure we understood the work and how to do it on our own.”

“Professor Shakya was always willing to help students in class if they had any questions about the content in front of them. He also allowed students to ask questions one on one directly after class. He frequently asked if students needed any clarification and if they were able to understand the content.”

“Anytime I had a question, Dr. Shakya was always prompt to answer it. Also, while assignments had hard deadlines, Dr. Shakya was merciful and gave people wiggle room if they had missed the date for legitimate reasons.”

“He taught this class very well especially considering I didn’t think I would understand the material well but I ended up doing better than I thought. He explains the material throughly and in an easy way to understand. Although I wish there was more feedback on assignments or that he would’ve went over more missed questions on the homework’s or quizzes.”

“Great teaching and responding to emails, he cares about you a lot and will take time out of class to help you.”

“Professor Shakya is knowledgeable and passionate about his subject. He is able to teach in a manner that works for most students and is willing to adapt for one–on–one instruction as needed. An enjoyable professor who is fair, reasonable, and an excellent instructor.”

“Don’t ever wanna lose contact with this prof, amazing teacher.”

“Professor Shakya was kind to the students and did his best to engage them in the course content. He allowed us to ask him questions on specific topics of interest in the classroom so that we were able to learn more. He also switched up the methods of displaying the content, from writing on the blackboard to a slideshow to showing videos, the diversity in the display of content kept it interesting.”

“He is a very high–energy professor and loves to teach students and it is very prevalent in the way the class is run. He gave us real–world examples that we can apply to our life.”

“The professor is very effective in giving and helping us retain information, along with adding new topics.”

“He explained the material throughly. He was always willing to help if we had any questions. He always was always checking in on us to make sure we were not only doing well in his class but in other classes. The way the course was set up was easy to understand and I think he should continue to do it the same way.”

“I would like to see Professor Shakya stay at Shippensburg. It is important to have younger professors who understand a bit more about technology and who are able to have a fresh perspective and energy.”

“I’m an economics major and had to take this course as a requirement. I thought Professor Shakya did a great job in helping me understand the content. He was always willing to answer questions and was very fun. You can tell that he cares and wants us to succeed.”

“It shed some light on the complexity of economic issues our country and the world struggles to balance. I felt that it was just about the right amount of hardness for an introductory course. You had to pay attention but I didn’t feel overloaded by the course.”

“He made the class fun and interesting. He also was kind when understanding we are busy with other classes. Shows real world problems.”

“The best aspect of this course is Dr. Shakya showing real–world examples of macroeconomic concepts in practice. It has aided my understanding of the concepts and their importance.”

“The grading system was one of the best aspects. Every assignment would be graded quickly and updated in D2L so I always knew what my grade was. The assignments directly told you what the correct answer was even if you got it incorrect.”

“He is a great teacher, has such a nice positive attitude that makes you want to go to class. The only thing I feel like I disliked about the course is that it is hard to keep on track because he does not clarify due dates or he is very disorganized with this course.”

Selected Student Comments Shippensburg University Spring 2021

“I enjoyed how this course was about applying concepts learned directly into projects, assignments, etc. I found it to be very helpful as it allowed me to further develop critical thinking and analytical skills, which I will take with me upon graduation. I also felt you had a lot of passion for helping your students, and I appreciated (and still do) how willing you were to provide assistance and even forward opportunities that would excel my remaining college experience.”

“This course was harder than I thought it was going to be. Dr Shakya used humor to alleviate the tension. I would definitely tell other students to take this course with this professor.”

“The most positive aspect was getting support and help from Professor Shakya and he was always understanding with my shortcomings.”

“Shishir is a great professor who clearly has the best interest of his students in mind.”

“Big workload but manageable”

“The most positive aspect of this class was the layout of the work. From the beginning, we knew how many points each week was worth and exactly what dates the homework was due on. Another thing that I thought was good was the fact that Professor Shakya took a class that I thought was going to be extremely boring and hard and made it interesting.”

“he was willing to move the quizzes to times that would work for students who had conflicts with work / sports”

“The positive aspect of this class is the videos that teaches you the formulas”

“For the most part the material was interesting and I appreciated the detailed outline in the syllabus regarding the grading structure.”

“I cannot think of anything that I would change about this course.”

“Dr. Shakya is very elaborate in his teaching, he provides lots of practice and examples, and makes class enjoyable to be in”

“I am satisfied with the way that Professor Shakya teaches this course. I just think the examples used need to be more practical so that I can understand them better.”

“I think he works really hard to try to get all of his students involved and discussing the content matter.”

“I would say to move more slowly through the material, but I know that is a not a reasonable request for a college course”

“The amount of assignments given in this course was honestly too much for a gen ed. I took it thinking it would be fairly easy, but it takes away so much of my study time for other classes.”

“Shishir is passionate about the topics discussed in the corse and has extensive experience with the topics discussed. When he gives anecdotes about what he has done with what is being discussed it really puts into perspective how the topic is used and what is possible with what is being taught.”

“Dr. Shakya tried his best to appease the class although in his shoes I can understand it can be difficult to strive too far from the original structure. He always remained positive and provided ample opportunities for feedback.”

“This course was effective in teaching me how to analyze big data and understand the bigger concepts. I liked how we learned about different perspectives of data and how the affect one another.”

Selected Student Comments Shippensburg University Fall 2020

“Professor Shakya is a wonderful man. He connects with his students, he wants the best for us and on top of that, he makes us laugh every time we have class. Overall, he is really good at his job and I truly appreciate him for everything.”

“Professor Shakya was a very understanding and nice guy. He made this class easy to learn in and was very engaging.”

“I feel that Professor Shakya is very passionate about this course and that made it very easy to pay attention and learn the materials. Economics was a new topic for me this semester and his passion helped make the topic easier to learn.”

“This class is a ton of work but professor Shakya made it very manageable. He made this course very fun and interesting.”

“Professor Shakya was very considerate and helpful anytime anything was needed. Energetic personality.”

“I wouldn’t change a thing. The work load was a little much, but in the end, it helped a lot because it prepared us for the quizzes.”

“I would not recommend any specific changes to this course.”

“I really enjoy attending class because you are a great speaker and you help the class understand things very well. You are also very accommodating and I really appreciated that.”

“The professor always offered additional support for students who were struggling, and consistently made sure to answer any questions or doubts.”

“Professor Shishir Shakaya is a fantastic person and is super understanding when things happen in our personal lives. He is willing to change dates and things and is very personable.”

“You were very enthusiastic about the material and were very nice, despite not being in person I still enjoyed your teaching.”

“Economics was a difficult subject to learn about, and I’m sure it can be just as difficult to teach. However, the professor structured his class very well and he helped students feel comfortable enough to ask questions.”

Instructor of Record, West Virginia University

  • Econ 225: Elementary Business and Economic Statistics Spring 2020
  • Econ 225: Elementary Business and Economic Statistics Fall 2020
  • Econ 225: Elementary Business and Economic Statistics Summer 2019
  • Econ 202: Principles of Macroeconomics Spring 2019

Other Teaching Related Experiences, West Virginia University

  • Econ 721: Mathematical Economics (TA, PhD Econ course, teaching 30% of course) Fall 2018
  • BUDA 550: Business Data Visualization (Online course design) Summer 2017 & 2018

Selected Student Comments West Virginia University

“I thought this class was well thought out and organized in a logical manner. The instructor was helpful and positive in his feedback and general statements to the class. One of the better classes I’ve taken at WVU and other colleges.”

“…the instructor had answered questions regarding assignments quickly and was able to offer help when needed…”

“…all the assignments were organized and clearly explained to us helped my learning experience greatly. Also, the fact that the instructor emailed us frequently and kept in contact with us all semester was great.”

“Shishir was always willing to help and was great at reminding us about assignments which I found very helpful.”

“The syllabus was very clear, and the professor was always open to answering any questions.”

“The additional programming part was useful, and it would be better if we had more than three classes for programming. Otherwise, everything went well.”

“Having the slides sent to us to help us review. Also making the exams online and taking them when we want during the day, gave us more time to take the exam and made it less stressful.”

“Connecting topics to real-world examples, along with his positive attitude to teaching Macroeconomics. He made the course interesting.”

“The lecture slides and the written notes were extremely helpful personally.”
